Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: SEA-LEVEL RISE AND SALT-MARSH RESPONSE: A PALEO PERSPECTIVE
Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate projections of future relative sea-level (RSL) rise are crucial for effective management of coastal populations, infrastructure, and ecosystems including salt marshes. Sea-level reconstructions from the last 4000 years provide a context for understanding modern and projected rates of sea-level rise because Earth's climate system is relatively unchanged. We will develop two new proxy RSL reconstructions from North Carolina to identify positive and negative departures from the perceived stability of sea level during the last 4000 years and support development of new predictive models in which the sea level-climate relationship can vary through time. The reconstructions will test the widely held assumption that sea-level rise from melting of large ice sheets was negligible during the last 2000 years and will help constrain rates of vertical land level movement. Data generated for the reconstructions will be used to further develop a model of salt-marsh response to sea-level rise that will provide a valuable service and tool to the coastal management community for informing policy decisions.

While there are compilations of global and regional proxy temperature data for the late Holocene, little is known about sea-level variability during this period and the response of sea level to known climate deviations such as the Medieval Climate Anomaly, Little Ice Age, and 20th century warming is unknown. Using foraminifera preserved in North Carolina salt-marsh sediments, we will produce the first continuous, high resolution (decadal and decimeter) RSL reconstruction spanning the last ~4000 years. The sea-level reconstructions will calibrate new predictive models of sea-level rise to improve the accuracy and regional validity of projections. The new record will extend existing reconstructions to test the following hypotheses that are vital for understanding the climate sea-level relationship: (1) regional RSL was stable before AD 1000; and (2) the contribution from melting of large ice sheets sea-level rise ended 2000 years ago. Reconstructions derived from salt marsh sediment also provide a paleo perspective for predicting the ecological effects of future sea-level rise. The proxy sea-level record will validate, for the first time, the Marsh Equilibrium Model (MEM). The MEM describes the regulation of salt-marsh vegetation by changes in sea level. If sea-level rise is faster than the rate of salt-marsh sediment accretion, the productivity of salt-marsh vegetation will decline, resulting in the degradation or loss of these important coastal ecosystems. The proxy sea level record will test a central premise of the MEM that (3) Stable sediment organic matter (SOM) concentration varies inversely with the reconstructed rate of RSL-rise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rate of relative sea-level rise along the US Atlantic and Gulf coasts increased throughout the 20th century. Whilst there is widespread agreement that it will continue to accelerate during the 21st century, great uncertainty surrounds its magnitude and geographic variability. Here, proxy-based reconstructions from the past 3000 years from North Carolina provide an appropriate context for understanding the significance and causes of modern and projected rates of sea-level rise. 

During the past 3,000 years, relative sea-level rise in North Carolina (~0.5 to 1.1 mm/y) was driven primarily by ongoing glacio-isostatic adjustment, with a modest, sub-regional-scale contribution from tectonic uplift along the Cape Fear Arch. The spatial pattern of relative sea-level change in North Carolina cannot be adequately explained by tidal range change through time, despite new geological evidence for opening and closing on the Outer Banks barrier islands during the past 3000 years. The pre-19th century relative sea-level variability at Roanoke Island (and other sites north of Cape Hatteras) coupled with stability at Cedar Island (and other sites south of Cape Hatteras) provides evidence that ocean dynamic processes were a driver of regional-scale sea-level trends. In addition, the new relative sea level reconstructions provide empirical data that is important for testing, refining, and parameterizing the Marsh Equilibrium Model (MEM). The MEM describes the regulation of salt-marsh vegetation by changes in sea level.

We evaluated sea-level trajectories for North Carolina from tide gauge records and sea-level proxies. It is extremely likely (P=0.95) that 20th century sea-level rise (2.6 ± 0.5 mm/y at Sand Point, NC) was faster than during any other century in 2300 years. Projections based on a combination of process models, statistical models, and expert elicitation and assessment indicate that, relative sea level at Wilmington, NC, is very likely to rise by 42–132 cm between 2000 and 2100 under the high-emissions RCP 8.5 pathway. Under all emission pathways, 21st century sea-level rise is very likely (P>0.90) faster than during the 20th century. Sea-level rise will increase the frequency of future coastal flooding; the current ‘1-in-100 year’ flood is expected to occur in ~30 of the 50 years between 2050-2100 under RCP 8.5.

Based upon these and other results, we published eleven peer reviewed papers, including one in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) that is currently in the 99th percentile (ranked 2) of the 1100 tracked articles of a similar age in PNAS. Our results informed national and state sea-level rise committees, indeed our PNAS paper was discussed in a senate floor speech by Senator Sheldon Whitehouse. Funding has exposed a post-doctoral scientist and graduate and undergraduate students to interdisciplinary concepts in ecology, geology and oceanography and promoted multi-disciplinary intellectual exchange among all team members. Support for research participation by students at Bryn Mawr College, a principally undergraduate women’s college, directly benefited an underrepresented group in geoscience (women).
